recommended_movies: Some Folks Call It a Sling Blade (1993)
Old Man and the Sea, The (1958)

simulated_ratings.title: Passion of the Christ, The (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Visceral and sincere, but the relentless brutality overwhelms the spirituality for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Misérables, Les (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A sturdy moral tale of guilt and grace that moved me more in its quiet moments than its romance.

simulated_ratings.title: Man from Earth, The (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Talky, idea-driven sci-fi that respects the audience and kept me debating long after.

simulated_ratings.title: Bill Hicks: Sane Man (1989)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Scathing, smart and cathartic stand-up with enough bite to outlast its era.

simulated_ratings.title: Room, The (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clever locked-room premise, though the tone wobbles and the comedy undercuts the mystery.

simulated_ratings.title: For Whom the Bell Tolls (1943)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Earnest, old-fashioned war romance with stakes I could invest in despite the melodrama.

simulated_ratings.title: Postman, The (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: I like the hopeful angle, but the mythmaking feels heavy-handed and drawn out.

simulated_ratings.title: Vanilla Sky (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Intriguing concept dulled by glossy melodrama and overdetermined twists.

simulated_ratings.title: Ben X (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Empathetic and tense, with the gaming angle giving the bullying story fresh texture.

simulated_ratings.title: Illuminata (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Fussy backstage theatrics that felt arch more than affecting.

simulated_ratings.title: Interstellar (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Ambitious and heartfelt, but the sentiment and exposition sometimes smother the wonder.

simulated_ratings.title: Brüno (Bruno) (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Provocation for its own sake wears thin and the jokes feel more mean than revealing.

simulated_ratings.title: Matewan (1987)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Stirring, human labor drama that treats solidarity and injustice with clear-eyed respect.

simulated_ratings.title: Midsommar (2019)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Beautifully crafted dread that I found more punishing than rewarding.

simulated_ratings.title: Mr. Nobody (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Big ideas and pretty images, but the fragmentation left me cold.

simulated_ratings.title: Old Man and the Sea, The (1958)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Simple, stubborn perseverance told with dignity that quietly hooked me.

simulated_ratings.title: No Escape (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tense setup undercut by simplistic, manipulative thrills.

simulated_ratings.title: Waco: The Rules of Engagement (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Riveting, troubling inquiry into power and accountability that sticks in the gut.

simulated_ratings.title: Inception (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Ingenious and propulsive, if a bit emotionally remote for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Joker (2019)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Committed character study whose bleakness is compelling even when it leans on familiar beats.

simulated_ratings.title: Steam of Life (Miesten vuoro) (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Unadorned, intimate confessions that feel disarmingly honest.

simulated_ratings.title: Disconnect (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A neat high-concept that engages the mind even as the execution feels slightly schematic.

simulated_ratings.title: Spitfire Grill, The (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gentle, earnest redemption story that won me over despite some sentimentality.

simulated_ratings.title: Birth of a Nation, The (1915)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Technically notable but morally poisonous and impossible to endorse.

simulated_ratings.title: Fountain, The (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sincere and ambitious, yet the metaphysical flourishes feel airless and self-important.

simulated_ratings.title: Braveheart (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Rousing and grim in equal measure, but its broad strokes blunt the impact.

simulated_ratings.title: Jeremiah Johnson (1972)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Spare and rugged, a character piece I respected more than I loved.

recommended_movies: Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery (1997)
À nous la liberté (Freedom for Us) (1931)
Man Who Knew Too Little, The (1997)
Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me (1999)
Anchorman: The Legend of Ron Burgundy (2004)

Santa Claus Is a Stinker (Le Père Noël est une ordure) (1982)

simulated_ratings.title: Impostors, The (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Broad farce with some charm, but the contrivances wore thin for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Goofy and occasionally clever, but the mugging and one-note gags tire me out.

simulated_ratings.title: À nous la liberté (Freedom for Us) (1931)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Wry, humane satire whose craft and gentle bite outweigh the dated trappings.

simulated_ratings.title: Dumb & Dumber (Dumb and Dumber) (1994)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Some inspired stupidity, but the relentless idiocy is more numbing than delightful.

simulated_ratings.title: Babette's Feast (Babettes gæstebud) (1987)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A quietly generous parable of grace and community that left me warmed and humbled.

simulated_ratings.title: Love Letter, The (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Pleasant idea, but the whimsy and small-town hijinks felt a little weightless to me.

simulated_ratings.title: Gods Must Be Crazy, The (1980)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A playful fable with rough edges

simulated_ratings.title: Signal, The (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Low-key, morally gray noir against a charged political backdrop hits a satisfying, thoughtful groove.

simulated_ratings.title: Man Who Knew Too Little, The (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Light and affable, though the mistaken-identity gag wears out before the finale.

simulated_ratings.title: Fearless Faith (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sincere, but the didactic arc and tidy revelations kept me at arm’s length.

simulated_ratings.title: Tropic Thunder (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Broad, rowdy Hollywood satire that made me laugh even as the bombast blunts the sting.

simulated_ratings.title: Wrongfully Accused (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Relentless spoofing with a scattershot hit rate that left me mostly cold.

simulated_ratings.title: Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: More of the same—some goofy highs, plenty of tired winks.

simulated_ratings.title: All That Jazz (1979)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A bracing, self-lacerating showbiz confessional whose intensity impressed me more than it moved me.

simulated_ratings.title: Pest, The (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grating, frantic shtick that felt more punishing than funny.

simulated_ratings.title: Anchorman: The Legend of Ron Burgundy (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Absurdist silliness that lands enough quotable gags to outweigh the smugness.

simulated_ratings.title: The Pit and the Pendulum (1991)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grand guignol flourishes aside, the cruelty and melodrama wore me down.

simulated_ratings.title: Santa Claus Is a Stinker (Le Père Noël est une ordure) (1982)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Acrid holiday farce with flashes of bite, but the chaos left me more weary than amused.

simulated_ratings.title: Bedazzled (1967)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A breezy, devilish romp whose playful conceit kept a smile on my face.

simulated_ratings.title: Becket (1964)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lean, compelling power struggle about conscience and authority that hits my sweet spot.

simulated_ratings.title: Raven, The (1963)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Light, campy magic that’s amiable if ultimately insubstantial for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Yellow Rock (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Handsome scenery, familiar beats

simulated_ratings.title: Amelie (Fabuleux destin d'Amélie Poulain, Le) (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Whimsical and tender, occasionally too cutesy, but its generosity won me over.

simulated_ratings.title: English Patient, The (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Handsomely mounted romance whose sweep I admired more than I felt.

simulated_ratings.title: Tomiris (2019)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Rousing and sincere, though the mythmaking can feel heavy-handed.

simulated_ratings.title: Official Story, The (La historia oficial) (1985)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quietly devastating moral inquiry that stuck with me long after.

simulated_ratings.title: No (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A sharp, hopeful political chronicle that finds real human stakes in strategy and slogans.

recommended_movies: Ivan Vasilievich: Back to the Future (Ivan Vasilievich menyaet professiyu) (1973)
Dora and the Lost City of Gold (2019)

simulated_ratings.title: Metallica: Some Kind of Monster (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Candid group-therapy and ego-wrangling more compelling to me than the album-making soap.

simulated_ratings.title: Final Destination (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A clever hook dulled by mechanical, mean-spirited deaths.

simulated_ratings.title: The Hunger Games: Catching Fire (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The uprising undercurrents and media manipulation engage me more than the arena spectacle.

simulated_ratings.title: The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 1 (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The propaganda chess and trauma ring truer than the stretched pacing.

simulated_ratings.title: Song of the South (1946)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Folksy veneer can’t mask regressive, harmful nostalgia I can’t endorse.

simulated_ratings.title: Twin Falls Idaho (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A gentle, oddball compassion piece whose empathy outweighs its quirks.

simulated_ratings.title: Final Destination 3 (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: More baroque fatalism with little to chew on beyond creative carnage.

simulated_ratings.title: Eye of the Beholder (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A glossy, moody surveillance tale whose opacity kept me at arm’s length.

simulated_ratings.title: Kung Pow: Enter the Fist (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A one-joke gag reel whose goofiness wears thin fast.

simulated_ratings.title: The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 2 (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The grim costs land, but the bombast blunts the poignancy.

simulated_ratings.title: Mystery Men (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: An affable goof on superhero tropes with enough charm to offset the bloat.

simulated_ratings.title: Paranormal Activity 3 (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Slow-burn haunts that feel more like a patience test than dread.

simulated_ratings.title: Being 17 (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A tender, clear-eyed coming-of-age that earns its bruised empathy.

simulated_ratings.title: Ivan Vasilievich: Back to the Future (Ivan Vasilievich menyaet professiyu) (1973)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Silly, inventive time-swap farce whose playful satire wins more smiles than laughs.

simulated_ratings.title: Grown Ups 2 (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lazy, elbow-in-the-ribs antics that mostly left me weary.

simulated_ratings.title: Blended (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Well-meaning, but the sitcom contrivances smother the heart.

simulated_ratings.title: The Interview (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Occasional laughs, but the shock-jock swagger outweighs sharper satire.

simulated_ratings.title: Kin-Dza-Dza! (1986)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bleakly funny, inventive satire whose humanism and social bite stuck with me.

simulated_ratings.title: Dante 01 (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A moody sci-fi parable whose heavy metaphysics left me cold.

simulated_ratings.title: This Is the End (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Self-indulgent yet sporadically funny, with an apocalypse that plays mostly as in-joke.

simulated_ratings.title: Goodbye Lover (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A slick, wry noir puzzle that amuses more than it compels.

simulated_ratings.title: Dora and the Lost City of Gold (2019)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A cheerfully earnest, lightweight adventure whose sincerity wins some goodwill.

simulated_ratings.title: Girlfriends of Christmas Past (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cute premise, but formula and sugary tidiness left me unmoved.

simulated_ratings.title: The Drifter (1988)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sleazy, serviceable stalker thrills with little psychological depth for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Sergio (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A compassionate, clear-eyed look at idealism and realpolitik that lingered with me.

simulated_ratings.title: Postal (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Crude, scattershot provocation that felt more punishing than pointed.

simulated_ratings.title: Adventures of Pinocchio, The (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A sincere fable whose charm is blunted by creaky storytelling.

simulated_ratings.title: The Hunger Games (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A sturdy, unsettling premise whose social critique hooked me more than the spectacle.

simulated_ratings.title: Dumb and Dumber To (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Nostalgic bits aside, the recycled idiocy mostly numbed me.

simulated_ratings.title: Serbian Film, A (Srpski film) (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Exploitative cruelty masquerading as transgression—I want no part of it.

simulated_ratings.title: Drop Dead Gorgeous (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Dark small-town mock-doc satire whose bite lands even as the meanness dulls the laughs.

simulated_ratings.title: U2: Rattle and Hum (1988)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Impressive stagecraft and flashes of intensity, but I prefer more probing, human-focused docs.

simulated_ratings.title: Angel Heart (1987)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Smoky, moody noir trappings, but the occult nastiness left me cold.

simulated_ratings.title: Closer (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A sharp, chilly chamber piece on desire and deceit that I admired more than loved.

simulated_ratings.title: Shopgirl (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Delicate and sincere, but the fairytale gloss and tidy lessons feel a bit weightless to me.

simulated_ratings.title: Zeitgeist: Moving Forward (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Ambitious and provocative, yet too sweeping and didactic to fully convince me.

simulated_ratings.title: The Deserted Station (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quiet, humane encounters that find grace in small acts—gently moving.

simulated_ratings.title: Phish: Bittersweet Motel (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A lively tour snapshot with an engaging subculture, but light on the human stakes I crave.

simulated_ratings.title: Apocalypto (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Visceral and gripping, but the relentless brutality and mythmaking left me more drained than moved.

simulated_ratings.title: Last Supper, The (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A cheeky, troubling premise that pokes hypocrisy even as some smugness seeps in.

simulated_ratings.title: Drifting Clouds (Kauas pilvet karkaavat) (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Dry, humane resilience told with modest grace that quietly won me over.

simulated_ratings.title: Runaway Train (1985)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A muscular, relentless survival tale with enough human grit to keep me invested.

simulated_ratings.title: Lawn Dogs (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A tender, uneasy class fable whose bruised empathy outweighed the contrivances.

simulated_ratings.title: Love Affair (1994)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Earnest and polished, but the fated-romance beats felt more dutiful than stirring.

simulated_ratings.title: The Vanishing (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A brooding, fragmented life study that intrigued me in flashes but left me distant.

simulated_ratings.title: Poultrygeist: Night of the Chicken Dead (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gross-out shock and juvenile provocation that felt more punishing than pointed.

simulated_ratings.title: Twice Upon a Yesterday (a.k.a. Man with Rain in His Shoes, The) (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A gently whimsical second-chance tale whose sincerity carries it past some contrivances.

simulated_ratings.title: To Have, or Not (En avoir (ou pas)) (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Unvarnished, working-class tenderness that finds real feeling in modest lives.

simulated_ratings.title: The Attempt Against the Life of Maitre Labori (1899)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A curious historical snapshot whose appeal is mostly archival for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Your Friends and Neighbors (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Incisive but so caustic and misanthropic it kept me at a chilly remove.

simulated_ratings.title: Pink Flamingos (1972)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gleeful filth-as-provocation that reads as empty and punishing to me.

simulated_ratings.title: Candy (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A tender, bruising addiction romance that earns its sorrow without wallowing.

simulated_ratings.title: Man Bites Dog (C'est arrivé près de chez vous) (1992)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A clever conceit curdled by gleeful cruelty—the satire illuminates little for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Human Traffic (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Energetic, freewheeling snapshot of youth that amuses more than it moves me.

simulated_ratings.title: Raven Song (2022)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A wistful search for meaning that hits enough honest notes to linger a bit.

simulated_ratings.title: Happy Ending, The (1969)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A clear-eyed midlife reckoning whose quiet ache resonated despite some dated touches.

simulated_ratings.title: The Lovers (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Wry, gently observed marital zigzags I respected more than I felt.

simulated_ratings.title: Cocaine Cowboys (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A propulsive, troubling oral history that maps power and violence with bracing clarity.
